Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Existing catalytic converter systems use rare precious metals to catalyze exhaust gas. Decreasing the use of these metals has the potential to transform automotive pollution clean-up methods. This has important economic implications for the nation because a typical automobile catalytic converter contains about $100 of precious metals, adding about 700 million dollars per year to the total cost of cars sold in the US. Moreover, it has major environmental and geopolitical implications; mining of precious metals is environmentally damaging, and many of the best sources are outside of the US. Aerogels are lightweight, nano-porous materials with lots of surface area and good thermal properties. Catalytic aerogel materials have the potential to replace the precious metals while being both cost-effective and environmentally friendlier than current automotive catalysts. This project funds an interdisciplinary team of faculty and undergraduate students in Mechanical Engineering and Chemistry at Union College who are undertaking fundamental studies of catalytic aerogel materials and demonstrating the utility of these materials as catalysts to alleviate automotive pollution.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: Catalytically active aerogels have the potential to transform automotive pollution mitigation technologies by eliminating the use of rare precious metals in internal combustion engine exhaust after-treatment applications. Aerogels' unique physical properties, including high surface area, low density and good thermal stability, offer significant advantages for use as automotive catalysts. Union College researchers have developed a novel rapid supercritical extraction (RSCE) process for fabricating aerogels. This process offers significant potential advantages for cost effectively preparing catalytic aerogel materials, and for casting them in forms suited to practical applications in automotive catalysis. In this project the interdisciplinary Union College team is undertaking a systematic and iterative series of experiments to prepare, test and optimize catalytically active aerogel materials for eventual applications in automotive pollution mitigation. Specifically, the team is: (1) developing a fundamental understanding of the effect of aerogel precursor chemistry and processing conditions on the bulk physical properties of catalytic aerogel materials prepared via their RSCE process, (2) extending knowledge of the performance of catalytic aerogel materials through strength testing and measurements of the thermal stability, flow-through characteristics, hydrophobicity and catalytic ability of the catalytic aerogel materials, and (3) demonstrating that RSCE catalytic aerogel materials can be fabricated into forms rugged and robust enough for ultimate application as three-way automotive catalysts under realistic service conditions. This project provides undergraduate students from Union's Mechanical Engineering and Chemistry Departments with exciting and relevant cross-disciplinary research experiences, which encourages them to consider graduate studies and careers in research and, therefore, impacts positively the US scientific infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aerogel materials show great promise for a wide variety of applications due to their combination of unique physical properties.  Aerogels have a nanoporous structure with high surface area, low density, low thermal and electrical conductivity, good thermal stability and an ability to be chemically tailored for different tasks. One particularly challenging and important application where aerogels offer a potential advantage is in the after-treatment of automotive (internal combustion engine) exhaust. Tailored catalytic aerogel materials have potential to provide a sustainable approach to automotive pollution mitigation by replacing or reducing the amount of precious metal catalysts, and thereby have a significant positive economic and environmental impact on this nation.

 

With support from this grant, the Union College Aerogel Lab developed and characterized 12 different types of aerogels: Alumina, Nickel-Alumina, Cobalt-Alumina, Copper-Alumina, Vanadia-Alumina, Vanadia-Silica, Cobalt-Silica, Copper-Silica, Copper-Nanoparticle-Silica, Vanadia-Titania, and Vanadia-Titania-Silica, Vanadia-Cobalt-Alumina. These aerogels were produced using a patented rapid supercritical extraction method that is significantly faster and more eco-friendly than other methods. These aerogels were tested for catalytic activity under conditions mimicking those found in automotive catalytic converters and all showed activity for one or more of the reactions important to automotive pollutant catalysis. The copper-alumina aerogels were found to be particularly attractive in three-way catalytic activity, exhibiting the ability to reduce nitrogen oxides while simultaneously oxidizing hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide.

This research has enabled the Union College mechanical engineering and chemistry departments to involve undergraduate students in exciting, relevant and productive cross­disciplinary research and add to the technical infrastructure of the country.  Over the 4.5 yr grant period, 27 students have participated directly in this research. 100% of the students either completed their degrees in four years or are currently on track to graduate in four years. Of the 18 who have graduated, 12 went on directly to graduate studies in engineering or chemistry, 3 to medical school, 1 to a Fulbright Fellowship and 2 are employed in STEM fields. 33% of these students are female, 3 are underrepresented minorities and 2 are high school students. Two of the students are Goldwater Scholarship recipients and two were named Goldwater Honorable Mentions. To date, ten of these students are co-authors on peer-reviewed publications and fourteen students presented work related to this project at regional and/or national conferences.  Students who worked directly on the project gained the most, but at a college like Union, students interact with each other (especially over the summer) informally and in weekly departmental seminars, group meetings, and journal clubs, at conferences, and at professional club functions. Knowledge, attitudes, and ideas percolate through the whole group, so this grant, in support of the Union College Aerogel Lab, has had a significant, positive educational impact on hundreds of students beyond those who participated directly in the project. https://muse.union.edu/aerogels/
